Abstract: American officials fear that delays in completing waste-water treatment site at Zvezda military shipyard could hurt efforts to reduce nuclear weapons in Russia; Zvezda receives millions of dollars in United States Cooperative Threat Reduction funds to help Russia meet its treaty obligations to dismantle and destroy weapons of mass destruction; work is incomplete almost four years into Japanese-financed project to build liquid radioactive waste treatment facility at Zvezda; American contractor, McDermott International Inc, complains of what it calls intentional delays to inflate bills; it is unclear how Russia even can afford to run treatment site, once it is up and running; Japanese agreed to finance operation, fearing that nuclear waste would be dumped into sea they share with Russia; shipyard's workers, who are owed months of wages, are growing restive, and Zvezda's director refuses to comment on delays; maps (M)
Snippet: American officials fear that delays in completing waste-water treatment site at Zvezda military shipyard could hurt efforts to reduce nuclear weapons in Russia; Zvezda receives millions of dollars in United States Cooperative Threat Reduction fund...
LeadParagraph: As Western governments began spending hundreds of millions of dollars in recent years to help Russia dispose of nuclear weapons and treat radioactive waste, Zvezda seemed like an ideal place to do some of the work.

Headline.PrintHeadline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; Radioactive Waste and Unpaid Bills

Keywords.Name: subject
Keywords.Value: ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT
